caption: Figure 1: Regret comparison for weighted set cover with n = 15 and k = 4
description: This figure compares the performance of three different algorithms for the weighted set cover problem: SUB-UCB (the authors' proposed algorithm), UCB on all sets of size k, and ETCG (an existing explore-then-commit algorithm). The x-axis represents the time horizon T, and the y-axis represents the total regret.  The plot shows that SUB-UCB consistently outperforms the other two algorithms across various time horizons, demonstrating its efficiency in minimizing regret for submodular maximization with bandit feedback.

caption: Figure 1: Regret comparison for weighted set cover with n = 15 and k = 4
description: This figure compares the performance of several algorithms on a weighted set cover problem with 15 items and a cardinality constraint of 4.  The algorithms compared include SUB-UCB (the authors' proposed algorithm with different greedy stop levels),  ETCG (explore-then-commit greedy), and a standard UCB algorithm applied to all possible sets of size k. The y-axis represents the total regret, and the x-axis represents the time horizon T. The plot shows that SUB-UCB consistently outperforms ETCG and the standard UCB approach, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed method.  The results highlight the adaptive nature of SUB-UCB, which adjusts to different time horizons. For smaller time horizons, SUB-UCB and ETCG outperform the standard UCB approach, while for larger time horizons the advantage of SUB-UCB remains apparent.
